## ADDITIONAL MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 302, 154, 316]]<|/det|>
Paper 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[732, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 228, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 880, 604]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 219, 649]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 650, 728, 682]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[398, 73, 599, 90]]<|/det|>
Mathematical Formulae  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[437, 133, 561, 151]]<|/det|>
## 1. ALGEBRA  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 164, 240, 182]]<|/det|>
Quadratic Equation  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 194, 384, 212]]<|/det|>
For the equation \(ax^{2} + bx + c = 0\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 212, 581, 248]]<|/det|>
\[x = \frac{-b\pm\sqrt{b^{2} - 4ac}}{2a}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 271, 228, 288]]<|/det|>
Binomial Theorem  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 291, 752, 330]]<|/det|>
\[(a + b)^{n} = a^{n} + \binom{n}{1} a^{n - 1}b + \binom{n}{2} a^{n - 2}b^{2} + \ldots +\binom{n}{r} a^{n - r}b^{r} + \ldots +b^{n}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 345, 499, 381]]<|/det|>
where \(n\) is a positive integer and \(\binom{n}{r} = \frac{n!}{(n - r)!r!}\)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 410, 384, 427]]<|/det|>
Arithmetic series \(u_{n} = a + (n - 1)d\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 432, 534, 465]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{1}{2} n(a + l) = \frac{1}{2} n\left\{2a + (n - 1)d\right\}\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 488, 336, 505]]<|/det|>
Geometric series \(u_{n} = ar^{n - 1}\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[245, 509, 428, 577]]<|/det|>
\[S_{n} = \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r} (r\neq 1)\] \[S_{\infty} = \frac{a}{1 - r} (|r|< 1)\]  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[401, 610, 594, 628]]<|/det|>
## 2. TRIGONOMETRY  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 643, 156, 660]]<|/det|>
Identities  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 670, 584, 721]]<|/det|>
\[\sin^{2}A + \cos^{2}A = 1\] \[\sec^{2}A = 1 + \tan^{2}A\] \[\csc \mathrm{e}^{2}A = 1 + \cot^{2}A\]  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 765, 242, 782]]<|/det|>
Formulae for \(\Delta ABC\)  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[405, 791, 594, 826]]<|/det|>
\[\frac{a}{\sin A} = \frac{b}{\sin B} = \frac{c}{\sin C}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[403, 826, 594, 846]]<|/det|>
\[a^{2} = b^{2} + c^{2} - 2bc\cos A\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 852, 556, 881]]<|/det|>
\[\Delta = \frac{1}{2} bc\sin A\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 107]]<|/det|>
A line, \(L\), has equation \(4x + 5y = 9\). Points \(A\) and \(B\) have coordinates \((- 6, 7)\) and \((1, 9)\) respectively. Find the equation of the line parallel to \(L\) which passes through the mid-point of \(AB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 427, 92, 446]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 427, 485, 447]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\log_5(8x + 7) - \log_5 2x = 2\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 427, 920, 446]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 531, 89]]<|/det|>
A group of students, 4 girls and 3 boys, stand in line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 146, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 861, 120]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different ways the students can stand in line if there are no restrictions. [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 211, 146, 229]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 210, 920, 244]]<|/det|>
Find the number of different ways the students can stand in line if the 3 boys are next to each other. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 365, 144, 383]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 365, 920, 399]]<|/det|>
Cam and Dea are 2 of the girls. Find the number of ways the students can stand in line if Cam and Dea are not next to each other. [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 85, 94, 104]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 78, 848, 104]]<|/det|>
Find the \(x\)-coordinates of the points of intersection of the curves \(\frac{x^{2}}{4} +\frac{y^{2}}{9} = 1\) and \(y = \frac{3}{2x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 484, 123]]<|/det|>
Give your answers correct to 3 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 103, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 87, 734, 317]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 332, 920, 370]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the graph of \(y = |\operatorname {f}(x)|\), where \(\operatorname {f}(x)\) is a quadratic function. Write down the two possible expressions for \(\operatorname {f}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 351, 920, 370]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 459, 144, 477]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 456, 920, 496]]<|/det|>
The three roots of \(\mathrm{p}(x) = 0\), where \(\mathrm{p}(x) = 5x^{3} + ax^{2} + bx - 2\) are \(x = \frac{1}{5}\), \(x = n\) and \(x = n + 1\),

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 476, 920, 515]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) and \(b\) are positive integers and \(n\) is a negative integer. Find \(\mathrm{p}(x)\), simplifying your coefficients.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 496, 920, 514]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 99, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 143, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 75, 180, 94]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 73, 920, 112]]<|/det|>
Use the binomial theorem to expand \((1 + 3x)^{7}\) in ascending powers of \(x\), as far as the term in \(x^{3}\) . Simplify each term.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 88, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 339, 181, 358]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 337, 920, 361]]<|/det|>
Show that your expansion from **part (i)** gives the value of \(1.03^{7}\) as 1.23 to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 355, 920, 374]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 586, 144, 605]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 577, 655, 609]]<|/det|>
Find the term independent of \(x\) in the expansion of \(\left(\frac{x^{4}}{2} + \frac{2}{x}\right)^{15}\) .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 586, 920, 605]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 71, 96, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 71, 438, 90]]<|/det|>
In this question, all angles are in radians.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 144, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 608, 121]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(\sec^{2}\theta = \tan \theta +3\) for \(-\pi < \theta < \pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 102, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 440, 144, 459]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 435, 556, 470]]<|/det|>
Show that, for \(0 < \phi < \frac{\pi}{2}\), \(\frac{\tan \phi}{\sqrt{1 - \cos^2 \phi}} = \sec \phi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 440, 920, 460]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 737, 144, 756]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 732, 821, 761]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\csc x = -\frac{17}{8}\) and that \(\frac{3\pi}{2} < x < 2\pi\), find the exact value of \(\cot x\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 734, 920, 755]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[376, 83, 621, 282]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 300, 893, 339]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the sector \(AOB\) of a circle, centre \(O\) and radius \(15\mathrm{cm}\). Angle \(AOB\) is \(\frac{\pi}{6}\) radians. Point \(C\) lies on \(OB\) such that \(CB\) is \(a\mathrm{cm}\). \(AC\) is a straight line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 352, 146, 371]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 351, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of \(a\) such that the area of triangle \(AOC\) is equal to the area of the shaded region \(ACB\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 369, 920, 388]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 617, 146, 635]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 616, 920, 651]]<|/det|>
For the value of \(a\) found in **part (a)**, find the perimeter of the shaded region. Give your answer correct to 1 decimal place.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 631, 920, 650]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 72, 96, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 153]]<|/det|>
A vehicle travels along a straight, horizontal road. At time \(t = 0\) seconds, the vehicle, travelling at a velocity of \(w \mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\) , passes point \(O\). The vehicle travels at this constant velocity for 12 seconds. It then slows down, with constant deceleration, for 10 seconds until it reaches a velocity of \((w - 14) \mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\). It continues to travel at this velocity for 28 seconds until it reaches point \(A\), \(458 \mathrm{m}\) from \(O\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 314, 183]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(w\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 165, 920, 183]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 75, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 73, 920, 109]]<|/det|>
A particle moves in a straight line. The velocity, \(\nu \mathrm{ms}^{- 1}\) , of the particle at time \(t\) seconds, where \(t \geqslant 0\) , is given by \(\nu = (t - 4)(t - 5)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 120, 180, 139]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 120, 742, 140]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(t\) for which the acceleration of the particle is \(0 \mathrm{ms}^{- 2}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 121, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[148, 291, 180, 310]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 291, 776, 310]]<|/det|>
Find the set of values of \(t\) for which the velocity of the particle is negative.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 291, 920, 310]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 494, 180, 512]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 494, 792, 512]]<|/det|>
Find the distance travelled by the particle in the first 5 seconds of its motion.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 494, 920, 512]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>10</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Relative to an origin \(O\), the position vector of point \(P\) is \(3\mathbf{i} - 2\mathbf{j}\) and the position vector of point \(Q\) is \(8\mathbf{i} + 13\mathbf{j}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 116, 144, 135]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 114, 767, 138]]<|/det|>
The point \(R\) is such that \(\overrightarrow{PQ} = 5\overrightarrow{PR}\). Find the unit vector in the direction \(\overrightarrow{OR}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 118, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 475, 146, 494]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 475, 920, 496]]<|/det|>
The position vector of \(S\) relative to \(O\) is \(\lambda \mathbf{j}\). Given that \(R S\) is parallel to \(P Q\), find the value of \(\lambda\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 490, 920, 510]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 102, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>11</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 87, 779, 344]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 361, 920, 396]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows part of the graphs of \(y = 6 + \mathrm{e}^{4x - 5}\) and \(x = 2\). The line \(x = 2\) meets the curve at the point \(B(2, b)\) and the line \(AB\) is parallel to the \(x\)-axis. Find the area of the shaded region. [7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 473, 89]]<|/det|>
In this question all lengths are in centimetres.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 100, 761, 457]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 473, 725, 494]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a right triangular prism of height \(h\) inside a right pyramid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 490, 801, 510]]<|/det|>
The pyramid has a height of 12 and a base that is an equilateral triangle, \(ABC\), of side 8.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 505, 541, 526]]<|/det|>
The base of the prism sits on the base of the pyramid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 521, 801, 540]]<|/det|>
Points \(P\), \(Q\) and \(R\) lie on the edges \(OA\), \(OB\) and \(OC\), respectively, of the pyramid \(OABC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 536, 430, 556]]<|/det|>
Pyramids \(OABC\) and \(OPQR\) are similar.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 567, 144, 585]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 560, 920, 604]]<|/det|>
Show that the volume, \(V,\) of the triangular prism is given by \(V = \frac{\sqrt{3}}{9} (ah^{3} + bh^{2} + ch)\) where \(a,\) \(b\) and \(c\) are integers to be found.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 592, 918, 609]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 426, 146, 445]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 425, 920, 460]]<|/det|>
It is given that, as \(h\) varies, \(V\) has a maximum value. Find the value of \(h\) that gives this maximum value of \(V\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 444, 920, 463]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
